" But one [you]58-julia 'll try to profit by , "[172-the captain] [he]172-the captain said . [The Captain]172-the captain moved in [his]172-the captain chair . [He]172-the captain could have groaned aloud at the words , which represented precisely what [Julia]58-julia would not do . Unfortunately [his]172-the captain movement had much the same effect as [his]172-the captain groan would have done , [some one on the other side of the door]2701-some one on the other side of the door moved too , and in the opposite direction . It must have been [Julia]58-julia , [[her]58-julia father]210-her father was sure of it ; it was like [her]58-julia to do it ; [she]58-julia must have gone almost to the window ; [he]172-the captain could not make out what was said . [The man]820-the man was no doubt trying to buy the bulb ; a stray word here and there indicated that , but it was impossible to hear what offer was made . It was equally impossible to hear what [Julia]58-julia said ; [[her]58-julia father]210-her father only caught the inflection of [her]58-julia voice , but [he]210-her father was sure [she]58-julia was refusing . In disgust and anger [he]210-her father rose and , having pulled the jam to the side of the fire , went into [the garden]4034-the garden . There [he]210-her father took the hoe and started irritably to work on a bed near the front door ; it was some relief to [his]210-her father feelings to scratch the ground since [he]210-her father could not scratch anything else . In a little while [Cross]79-cross came out . " Well , if [you]58-julia wo n't , [you]58-julia wo n't , "[79-cross] [he]79-cross was saying as [Julia]58-julia opened the door . " [I]79-cross think [you]58-julia are making a mistake ; in fact , if [you]58-julia were n't [a lady]3390-a lady [I]79-cross should say [you]58-julia were acting rather like [a fool]3758-a fool ; but , of course , [you]58-julia must please [yourself]58-julia . If [you]58-julia think better of it [you]58-julia can always write to [me]79-cross . Just name the price , a reasonable price , that 's all [you]58-julia need do . [We]4312-we understand [one another]1574-one another , and [we]4312-we can do business without any fuss — [you]58-julia have [my]79-cross address ? "[79-cross] [He]79-cross gave [her]58-julia a card as [he]79-cross spoke , although [she]58-julia assured [him]79-cross [she]58-julia should not want it ; then [he]79-cross took [his]79-cross leave . [She]58-julia watched [him]79-cross go , tearing up the card when [he]79-cross had set off down [the road]3464-the road . [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington watched [her]58-julia . " What did [he]79-cross want ? "[79-cross] [he]79-cross asked , remembering that [he]79-cross was not supposed to know . " The bulb , "[58-julia] [she]58-julia answered . " And [you]79-cross would not sell it ? "[58-julia] " No . "[58-julia] [She]58-julia had come from [the doorstep]2707-the doorstep now to pull up some weeds [he]79-cross had overlooked . " [I]79-cross ca n't understand [you]58-julia , [Julia]58-julia , "[79-cross] [he]79-cross said resting on [his]79-cross hoe , and speaking as much in sorrow as in anger . " [You]58-julia seem to have so little sense of honour — [women]3573-women so seldom have — but [I]58-julia should have thought that [you]58-julia would have had a lesson on the necessity , the obligation of paying debts . When [you]58-julia come to think of the efforts [we]4315-we are making to pay those debts , how [I]58-julia am straining every nerve , giving almost the whole of [my]58-julia income , doing without everything but the barest necessaries , without some things that are necessaries in [my]58-julia state of health , what [[your]58-julia mother]3323-your mother is doing , how [she]3323-your mother has given up [[her]3323-your mother home]2418-her home , [[her]3323-your mother husband]230-her husband , to live almost on charity in [[[her]3323-your mother son - in - law]2051-her son - in - law 's house]4320-her son - in - law 's house . When [you]58-julia think of all that , [I]58-julia say , and of what [[your]58-julia sisters]4321-your sisters have done , it does seem strange that [you]58-julia should grudge this bulb , simply and solely because it was given [you]58-julia by [some people for whom [you]58-julia care nothing]4322-some people for whom you care nothing . "[58-julia] [Julia]58-julia agreed ; [she]58-julia never saw the purpose of contradicting when conviction was out of the question . " It does seem strange , "[58-julia] [she]58-julia said ; " but there is one comfort , the worst of the debts will be cleared off by the end of the year . [Uncle William]135-uncle william knows that and has arranged for it in [his]135-uncle william own mind ; [I]58-julia really think it would be almost a pity to disturb the business plans of any one so exact . "[58-julia] " Are [we]4323-we , "[172-the captain] [the Captain]172-the captain returned scornfully , " to pinch and save to the end of the year ? Am [I]172-the captain to do without the few comforts that might make life tolerable ? Am [I]172-the captain to work like [a farm labourer]2152-a farm labourer and live like one till then , because [you]210-her father choose to keep this bulb ? "[172-the captain] [Julia]58-julia thought it was very probable things would go on as they were for some time , but [she]58-julia did not say so ; [she]58-julia only said , " [I]58-julia am sorry [you]210-her father find it so trying . "[58-julia] " Trying ! "[210-her father] [[her]58-julia father]210-her father said , and stopped , as if [he]210-her father found the word and most others very inadequate . " After all , it does not much matter , "[210-her father] [he]210-her father remarked in a tone of gloomy resignation . " [I]210-her father sha n't be [here]371-here , in [any one]187-any one 's way , much longer ; there is not the least chance that [I]210-her father shall live till the end of the year , and when [I]210-her father am gone [you]58-julia can do what [you]58-julia please , what [you]58-julia must , with [your]58-julia bulb . [I]210-her father own [I]210-her father should like to see [you]58-julia a little more comfortable and better off now . [I]210-her father hate to have [you]58-julia doing [servant]4327-servant 's work and going shabby as [you]58-julia have to . [I]210-her father should like [you]58-julia to be decently dressed , taking [your]58-julia proper place in [society]4328-society , but if [you]58-julia think it right to go on as [you]58-julia are and to keep [your]58-julia bulb , of course [I]210-her father have nothing to say . "[210-her father] It was as well [he]2710-he had nothing , for [Julia]58-julia remembered the jam and went [indoors]2711-indoors , so [he]2710-he would have had [no one]181-no one to say it to . [She]58-julia went into [the back kitchen]2272-the back kitchen , thinking , but not of the jam . Once again the temptation to sell the daffodil beset [her]58-julia ; not to [Cross]79-cross , [he]2710-he was [the last man to whom [she]58-julia would have sold it]2714-the last man to whom she would have sold it , but to [some collector who would care for it as [the Van Heigens]78-the van heigens would]2715-some collector who would care for it as the van heigens would . [She]58-julia could easily find such a one with or without assistance from [Cross]79-cross ; little harm would be done to [the Van Heigens]78-the van heigens by it ; indeed [Joost]77-joost had expected [her]58-julia to do no less , and if [she]58-julia did it [she]58-julia could pay — not the debts [[her]58-julia father]210-her father had mentioned — but the one [he]77-joost had not . [She]58-julia had thought this all out before , seen the arguments on both sides , and arrived at [her]58-julia conclusion ; but there are some things that are not content with this treatment once , nor even twice , but demand it a good many more times than that . So [she]58-julia thought it out again and came again to the old conclusion . [Joost]77-joost had given [her]58-julia the bulb because [he]77-joost loved [her]58-julia ; [he]77-joost had made no conditions because [he]77-joost believed in [her]58-julia ; [he]77-joost had even professed [himself]77-joost content that [she]58-julia should sell it because , in [his]77-joost humbleness and generosity , [he]77-joost wanted only that [she]58-julia should get what ease [she]58-julia could . [He]77-joost was content to make what was to [him]77-joost a great sacrifice for no other reason than that [she]58-julia should have a little more money on mere caprice , the very nature of which [he]77-joost did not know . And so [she]58-julia could not do it , that was the end of the whole matter . [She]58-julia could not take the gift of [the man who loved [her]58-julia to pay a debt to [the man [she]58-julia loved]2718-the man she loved]2717-the man who loved her to pay a debt to the man she loved . [She]58-julia went to fetch jam pots , without calling [herself]58-julia to order for the last admission . It was the one luxury [she]58-julia had at that time ; daily and nightly [she]58-julia could admit to [herself]58-julia that [she]58-julia loved [him]77-joost and [he]77-joost loved [her]58-julia . Not exactly passionately — [they]2719-they were [not passionate people]2720-not passionate people , [she]58-julia told [herself]58-julia — but in an odd companionable equal sort of way which was the best in [the world]208-the world . Nothing would ever come of it , even in the remote future when [[her]58-julia father]210-her father was dead and the debt paid . By that time [both of [them]1370-both of them]1370-both of them would have grown old and set in [their]1370-both of them far separate ways , and even if [he]77-joost ever heard that [she]58-julia was free [he]77-joost would have become wiser and changed [his]77-joost mind . So there was no end to this thing , no awakening and disillusioning , none of the disappointment and dreariness which is likely to attend the translating of a dream into work - a - day life . For that reason it should have been possible to be content , even with the thing which stood between [her]58-julia and realisation — sometimes it almost was , at least [she]58-julia persuaded [herself]58-julia so . At others there were things harder to control ; brief moments when crushing down all opposition and obliterating other thoughts , came the memory of how [she]58-julia had crouched behind the chopping - block , how hidden [her]58-julia tears in [his]77-joost coat . There was no reason or common - sense in that , no friendship or good - fellowship in the clasp of [his]77-joost arms ; it was [the natural man]1137-the natural man and [the natural woman]2725-the natural woman , and absence could not change it , nor time take it away ; it had been , it might be again , it obeyed no law and answered to no argument in [the world]208-the world . It was something which made [her]58-julia ashamed and afraid and yet glad with a rare incommunical gladness that was pointed with pain . Just then the jam boiled over , and [she]58-julia had to leave [her]58-julia pots to run and save it . It is a great thing to have [your]2727-your mind under fair control ; the Polkington training , wherein the advisable and advantageous were compelled to rank high even in matter of emotion , is not without use in bringing this about . But it is also a great thing , almost , perhaps , a more important one for [some people]3545-some people , to have plenty to do even if it is only making jam . While [Julia]58-julia made [her]58-julia jam [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington hoed ; at least [he]77-joost did for a little while , then [he]77-joost gradually ceased and stood leaning upon [his]77-joost hoe , lost in unhappy thought . At last [he]77-joost moved , and , gathering the withering weeds that lay beside [the path]566-the path , carried them to an old basket which [he]77-joost had left beside the garden wall . With the weeds [he]77-joost picked up the torn fragments of card which [Julia]58-julia had dropped beside the doorstep ; [he]77-joost let them fall into the basket with the other rubbish , but when [he]77-joost saw them gleaming white among the green they arrested [his]77-joost attention . For a moment [he]77-joost looked at them , then [he]77-joost carefully picked them out ; [he]77-joost had some thought of appealing to [Julia]58-julia once more , or telling [her]58-julia that [he]77-joost had saved [the man]820-the man 's address for [her]58-julia and [she]58-julia had one last chance . [He]77-joost sat down on the wall ; would it be any good to appeal ? [he]77-joost asked [himself]77-joost despondently . Would anything be any good ? Was not everything a failure ? [No one]181-no one regarded [him]77-joost ; [Cross]79-cross , [the man whose card [he]77-joost held]2732-the man whose card he held , had not even glanced in [his]77-joost direction when [he]77-joost went down [the path]566-the path . [A miserable bargain - driving tradesman]2734-a miserable bargain - driving tradesman had passed [him]77-joost and paid no more attention to [him]77-joost than if [he]77-joost had been [a gardener]2735-a gardener ! [Gillat]57-johnny , [[his]77-joost own friend]2736-his own friend , did not regard [him]77-joost , thought nothing of [his]77-joost comforts ; [he]77-joost was all for [Julia]58-julia ; thought of nothing and [no one else]3400-no one else . As for [Julia]58-julia [herself]58-julia , [she]58-julia had not the slightest regard for [him]77-joost , no consideration , not even filial respect and obedience . [He]77-joost looked gloomily before [him]77-joost for a little , then [his]77-joost eye fell on the white fragments [he]77-joost held , the address of [the man who was anxious to buy the daffodil which [Julia]58-julia in [her]58-julia obstinate folly and selfish unreasonableness]2738-the man who was anxious to buy the daffodil which julia in her obstinate folly and selfish unreasonableness , would not sell . If it only were sold ! [He]77-joost thought over all the good things that could then be done ; they were the same as those excellent reasons that [he]77-joost had [himself]77-joost given a little while back . [Some people]3545-some people might have said they were rather diverse and not all mutually inclusive , but no such idea troubled [him]77-joost ; [he]77-joost was sure all could easily have been done if the daffodil were sold . [He]77-joost felt that [he]77-joost could have done it all quite well , [he]77-joost did not stop to think how — if [he]77-joost had had the handling of the money [he]77-joost could have been [a benefactor to [[his]77-joost whole family]2741-his whole family]2740-a benefactor to his whole family , especially [Julia]58-julia . It was hard that [he]77-joost should be prevented , bitterly hard ; it had so often happened in [his]77-joost life that [he]77-joost had been prevented from doing what was good and useful by want of means and opportunity or the stupid obstinacy of [other people]3728-other people . [He]77-joost grew more and more depressed as [he]77-joost sat on the wall thinking of these things and wondering if there were many men so useless , so unfortunate and misunderstood as [he]77-joost . This depression lasted all that day and on into the next ; indeed , for some time longer . It lifted a little once in the course of a week , but not much , and soon settled down again , making [the Captain]172-the captain very miserable , disinclined for work , and decidedly bad company . [Johnny]57-johnny thought [he]57-johnny was not well , but [Julia]58-julia fancied [his]57-johnny trouble had something to do with annoyance and the daffodil . [He]77-joost did not confide in either of [them]2744-them , maintaining a proud and gloomy silence and nursing [his]77-joost grievance so that it grew . For days [he]77-joost cherished [his]77-joost sense of injury and wrong , until it became large and took a good hold upon [him]77-joost . Then , all at once , for no reason that [one]3325-one can give , a change came , and [his]77-joost mind , as if smitten by a gust of wind , began to veer about , to stir and lighten . Why , [he]77-joost suddenly asked [himself]77-joost , was it that [Julia]58-julia would not sell the bulb ? Because — the answer was so absurdly simple [he]77-joost wondered it had not occurred to [him]77-joost before — because it was the [Van Heigens]78-the van heigens ' present , and [one]3325-one can not sell presents . [He]77-joost perfectly understood the scruple , honoured it even ; but [he]77-joost also saw quite plainly that , though it prevented [her]58-julia from selling the daffodil , it did not stand in the way of its being sold . [She]58-julia could not , of course , authorise the sale , any more than [she]58-julia could conduct it ; but that was no reason why [she]58-julia should not be very pleased to have it sold . Indeed , not only was this a probability , practically a certainty , but more than likely [she]58-julia had had some such idea in [her]58-julia mind when [she]58-julia spoke of the matter to [[her]58-julia father]210-her father — in all likelihood [she]58-julia was wondering now why [he]210-her father had not taken the hint . Thus [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington reasoned , seeing light at last in the dimness of the depression which had possessed [him]59-captain polkington . Quite how much [he]77-joost really believed , or even if [he]77-joost were capable of real reasonable belief at this stage of [his]77-joost career , it is not easy to say . It is possible [he]77-joost may have thought [he]77-joost was right for the time being ; [his]77-joost conscience was capable of remarkable gymnastic feats at times . It is also possible that [he]77-joost , like [some others of [the human race]2749-the human race]2748-some others of the human race , was not really able to think at all . Anyhow the depression that weighed upon [him]77-joost lifted , and [he]77-joost remembered with satisfaction that [he]77-joost had kept the torn fragments of [Cross]79-cross ' card . In the early part of the summer the hyacinths , tulips , and finer narcissus had been taken out of the ground and put to dry . [Julia]58-julia hoped by this means to get more and better flowers from [them]2750-them next year than is the case when they are left in [the earth]1361-the earth . [They]2750-them took some time to dry and were not really ready till the summer was far advanced ; but that did not matter to [her]58-julia , however it may have inconvenienced [[her]58-julia father]210-her father ; [she]58-julia was too busy to attend to [them]2750-them earlier . By the middle of August [they]2750-them were ready , and [she]58-julia set to cleaning them in [her]58-julia spare time with [Johnny]57-johnny to help [her]58-julia . [He]77-joost was proud and pleased to do so , and did not in the least mind the extreme irritation of the skin which befalls [those who rub off the old loose husks]2753-those who rub off the old loose husks . A place was prepared for the bulbs in [one of [the sheds]2755-the sheds]2754-one of the sheds , the wide shelf cleared and partitions made in [it]2754-one of the sheds by [Mr. Gillat]66-mr. gillat , who also spent some time in writing labels for each of [the divisions]2756-the divisions . [Julia]58-julia told [him]77-joost this was unnecessary as [she]58-julia knew by the shape which were hya cinths and which tulips ; still [he]77-joost did it . [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington did not offer any assistance ; [he]59-captain polkington merely looked on with indifferent interest ; the matter did not seem to concern [him]59-captain polkington . But one day , towards the end of the month , but before the bulbs were all done , [Julia]58-julia went into [the town]569-the town . [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington saw [her]58-julia start ; then [he]59-captain polkington wandered to [the shed]2758-the shed where [Johnny]57-johnny was at work . For a little [he]59-captain polkington stood watching , then [he]59-captain polkington walked leisurely round [the place]241-the place looking at this and that . " [You]58-julia will never be able to tell which is which of these things , "[59-captain polkington] [he]59-captain polkington remarked at last . [Johnny]57-johnny looked at [his]57-johnny somewhat conspicuous labels . " [I]57-johnny 've named them , do n't [you]172-the captain see ' Tulips ? ' "[57-johnny] " But [you]172-the captain do n't say what sort of tulips , which are red and which yellow . Nor what sort of narcissus , which are daffodils and which the bunchy things . "[59-captain polkington] " No , "[66-mr. gillat] [Mr. Gillat]66-mr. gillat admitted ; " no , [they]4329-they got mixed in the digging up ; [I]66-mr. gillat forgot , and put them all in the barrow together ; that 's how it happened . "[66-mr. gillat] " What ? The whole lot ? "[172-the captain] [the Captain]172-the captain inquired . " The streaked daffodil and all ? What did [Julia]58-julia say ? "[172-the captain] " [She]58-julia said it did not matter , "[57-johnny] [Johnny]57-johnny told [him]172-the captain ; " [they]4329-they 'll be all the more surprise to [us]4330-we when [they]4329-they come up next year . "[57-johnny] " [She]58-julia did n't mind , not even about the streaked daffodil ? "[172-the captain] " Oh , that was not there , "[66-mr. gillat] [Mr. Gillat]66-mr. gillat said , serenely unconscious that the fate of that bulb was the only interest . " [We]4330-we have got that by itself . "[66-mr. gillat] [He]66-mr. gillat showed a little piece of shelf penned off from the rest and carefully covered with wire netting for fear of rats . Three different shaped bulbs were there in a row . " That 's it , "[57-johnny] [Johnny]57-johnny said , pointing to one of the three . " And that end one is the red tulip with the black middle ; it is supposed to be very good ; and that other is the double blue hyacinth from down by the gate ; [we]4330-we are going to try it in a pot in [the house]175-the house next year and have it bloom early . "[57-johnny] [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington nodded , but did not show much interest . " Did [you]59-captain polkington put these here , or did [she]58-julia ? "[59-captain polkington] [he]59-captain polkington asked . " [She]58-julia did , "[57-johnny] [Johnny]57-johnny answered . " [She]58-julia cleans them much better than [I]57-johnny do , and [we]4330-we knew they were choice ones , the best one of each kind , so [she]58-julia cleaned them ; but [I]57-johnny made the wire cover . "[57-johnny] [The Captain]172-the captain did not praise the ingenuity of this contrivance , which [he]172-the captain did not admire at all , and soon afterwards [he]172-the captain sauntered back to [the house]175-the house . [He]66-mr. gillat was dozing in the easy - chair in [the front kitchen]2480-the front kitchen when [Johnny]57-johnny came in to change [his]57-johnny coat before setting out to meet [Julia]58-julia . [He]57-johnny did not seem to have moved much when [Mr. Gillat]66-mr. gillat came down - stairs ready to start . " What ? "[66-mr. gillat] [he]66-mr. gillat roused [himself]66-mr. gillat to say when [Johnny]57-johnny announced [his]57-johnny destination . " Oh , all right , [you]58-julia need not have waked [me]66-mr. gillat to tell [me]66-mr. gillat that , it really is of no importance to [me]66-mr. gillat if [you]58-julia like to walk in the blazing sun . "[66-mr. gillat] [He]66-mr. gillat settled [himself]66-mr. gillat afresh in the chair , muttering something about the heat , and [Johnny]57-johnny went out , quietly closing the door after [him]57-johnny . It was an hour later when [Julia]58-julia and [the faithful Johnny]2764-the faithful johnny came back , the latter decidedly hot although [he]66-mr. gillat was carrying one of the lightest of the parcels . [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington was still in [his]59-captain polkington chair ; [he]59-captain polkington woke up as [they]2765-they entered . " Why , "[59-captain polkington] [he]59-captain polkington said , " [I]59-captain polkington must have dropped asleep ! "[59-captain polkington] [He]59-captain polkington rose and went to take [Julia]58-julia 's parcels . " Let [me]59-captain polkington put these away for [you]58-julia , "[59-captain polkington] [he]59-captain polkington said solicitiously ; " it is a great deal too hot for [you]58-julia to be walking in the sun and carrying all these things . "[59-captain polkington] " Thank [you]59-captain polkington , "[58-julia] [Julia]58-julia answered ; " that 's all right . Perhaps [you]59-captain polkington would not mind getting the tea , though ; if [you]59-captain polkington would do that [I]58-julia should be glad . "[58-julia] [He]59-captain polkington did mind , but [he]59-captain polkington set about it , and it was perhaps well for [him]59-captain polkington that [he]59-captain polkington did , as otherwise [he]59-captain polkington might have paid a suspicious number of fidgety attentions to [Julia]58-julia . As it was , doing the menial work which [he]59-captain polkington always considered beneath [his]59-captain polkington dignity , while [Johnny]57-johnny sat still and rested , restored [him]57-johnny to [his]57-johnny usual manner . But [the Captain]172-the captain , though [he]172-the captain was safely past the initial difficulty , did not find the working out of [his]172-the captain scheme altogether easy . [He]172-the captain had the bulb , it is true , and [he]172-the captain was safe from detection for there was still under the wire cover a smooth yellow - brown narcissus root very like the first one ; but [he]172-the captain had got to get rid of it . It was not very easy to get a letter to the post here without remark from [Mr. Gillat]66-mr. gillat . That , in the circumstances , would be undesirable for it was likely to arouse [Julia]58-julia 's suspicions , and if [they]2767-they were roused [she]58-julia might think it [her]58-julia duty to interfere — even though , of course , [she]58-julia did wish the bulb sold . [[Her]58-julia father]210-her father recognised that and , determining not to give [her]58-julia the opportunity , got [his]210-her father letter written betimes and waited for a chance to give it to [the postman]2769-the postman unobserved . In writing [he]210-her father had been faced by one very great difficulty , [he]210-her father had not the least idea how much to ask . [Cross]79-cross had said " name a reasonable price , "[79-cross] and [he]210-her father must name one , or else it would appear that [he]210-her father were writing on [his]210-her father own behalf not [Julia]58-julia 's ; but [he]210-her father did not know what was reasonable and [he]210-her father had no chance of finding out . A new orchid , [he]210-her father had vaguely heard , was sometimes worth a hundred pounds ; but it was impossible [any one]187-any one should pay so much for a daffodil , an ordinary garden flower . [Julia]58-julia , whatever [her]58-julia motive , would not have refused to sell it if it would have fetched so much ; [he]210-her father could not con ceive of [a Polkington]2771-a polkington , especially a poor one , turning [her]58-julia back on a hundred pounds . For hours [he]210-her father thought about this and at last decided to ask twenty pounds . It seemed more to [him]210-her father now than it would have done a year ago , by reason of the small sums [he]210-her father had handled lately ; but it was a good deal less than [his]210-her father golden dreams had painted the bulb to be worth in the time when it seemed unattainable , and [he]210-her father was paying debts and providing for [Julia]58-julia out of the proceeds of the imaginary sale . Still , [he]210-her father finally decided to ask it and wrote to that effect , and after some waiting for the opportunity got the letter posted . After that there followed an unpleasant time or suspense , made the more unpleasant by the fact that [he]210-her father had to look out for [the postman]2769-the postman as [he]210-her father did not want the return letter to fall into [Julia]58-julia 's hands . At last , after a longer time than [he]210-her father expected , the reply came safely to hand . This was it — " [Sir]3376-sir , "[0-i] [I]0-i am obliged to decline [your]210-her father offer of the streaked daffodil bulb , the price [you]210-her father name being absurd . To tell the plain truth , [I]0-i would rather not do business with [you]210-her father in the matter ; [I]0-i prefer to deal with [principals]2773-principals , else in these cases there is little guarantee of good faith . " [Yours]210-her father faithfully , "[79-cross] [Alexander Cross]79-cross . " "[79-cross] P. S.—If [you]210-her father should fail to dispose of [your]210-her father bulb elsewhere and it would be a convenience to [you]210-her father , [I]0-i will give [you]210-her father a five pound note for it , that is , if [you]210-her father can guarantee it genuine . It is not , under the circumstances , worth more to [me]0-i . " A. C. "[172-the captain] So [the Captain]172-the captain read and then re - read ; anger , mortification and disappointment preventing [him]172-the captain from grasping the full meaning at first . Five pounds , only five pounds ! No wonder [Julia]58-julia would not sell [her]58-julia bulb ; no wonder [she]58-julia preferred to keep a present that would only fetch five pounds ! What was such a trifle ? [The Captain]172-the captain glared at the letter as [he]172-the captain asked [himself]172-the captain the question proudly . [His]172-the captain pride was badly wounded . [Cross]79-cross had not set [him]172-the captain right in [his]172-the captain mistaken idea of the daffodil 's value too politely ; at least [he]172-the captain thought not . Why should [he]172-the captain , [this tradesman]2776-this tradesman , say [he]172-the captain preferred to deal with [principals]2773-principals ? Did [he]172-the captain imagine that [a gentleman]3384-a gentleman would attempt to sell [him]172-the captain a spurious bulb ? [The Captain]172-the captain 's honour was not of that sort and [he]172-the captain felt outraged . [He]172-the captain felt outraged , too , almost insulted , at being told that the price was absurd . The absurd thing was that [he]172-the captain should be expected to know anything about trade or trade prices . " [The man]820-the man can have no idea of [my]172-the captain position , "[172-the captain] [he]172-the captain thought . But there [he]172-the captain was not quite correct ; it was precisely because [he]172-the captain had a suspicion of the position that [Cross]79-cross had written thus . [No one with any right to it]2780-no one with any right to it would offer the true bulb for twenty pounds ; either , so [he]172-the captain argued , it was stolen or not genuine ; which , [he]172-the captain did not know , the odds were about even . After making a few inquiries at [Marbridge]61-denah into [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington 's history [he]172-the captain came to the conclusion that the chance in favour of the true bulb was worth five pounds to [him]172-the captain . Accordingly [he]172-the captain offered it , indifferent as to the result , but rather anticipating [its]2781-its acceptance . [It]2781-its was accepted . [The Captain]172-the captain was mortified and disappointed , but five pounds is five pounds . It even seems a good deal more when [your]2783-your income is very small and the part of it which [you]2783-your handle [yourself]2783-your so much smaller as to amount to nothing worth mentioning . It was September now , and already the mornings and evenings were cold , foretaste of the winter which was coming , which would hold [the exposed land]2784-the exposed land in its grip for months . Five pounds would buy things which would make the winter more tolerable ; small comforts and luxuries meant a great deal to real poverty in cold weather and feeble health . Of course to [Johnny]57-johnny and [Julia]58-julia too ; [they]2785-they were all going to benefit . [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington packed the bulb in a small box and posted it when [he]172-the captain went to [Halgrave]47-halgrave to have [his]172-the captain hair cut . By return [he]172-the captain received a five pound note — a convenient handy form of money , easy to send , easy to change . [Halgrave]47-halgrave might not perhaps be able to give change for it without inconvenience , but [Julia]58-julia could get it changed next time [she]58-julia went into [town]238-town . That would not be just yet , but a note will keep ; it would perhaps be better to keep it for the present . [The Captain]172-the captain folded it in [his]172-the captain pocket - book and kept it .

It was not till [October]106-october that [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington was able to change the five pound note . This was really [Julia]58-julia 's fault , [she]58-julia went so seldom into [the town]569-the town ; [he]59-captain polkington had once or twice suggested [her]58-julia doing so when [she]58-julia said [they]2789-they wanted this or that , but [she]58-julia never took the hint , and the note was still in [his]59-captain polkington pocket - book . At last , however , the opportunity came . [[A keeper]2790-a keeper 's wife with whom [Julia]58-julia had got acquainted]2791-a keeper 's wife with whom julia had got acquainted had promised [her]58-julia a pair of lop - eared rabbits if [she]58-julia could come and fetch them . [She]58-julia was not very anxious to have them , but [Mr. Gillat]66-mr. gillat was ; [he]66-mr. gillat said they would be very profitable . [Julia]58-julia doubted this ; but , since [he]66-mr. gillat wanted them , [she]58-julia said [they]2789-they would have them , and accordingly , one morning , [they]2789-they started together with a basket for the rabbits . [They]2789-they started directly after breakfast for [they]2789-they had to go a long way across [the heath]4162-the heath and could not at the best be back before two o'clock . [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington watched [them]2789-they go , standing at the cottage door until [their]2789-they figures were small on the great expanse of heather . Then [he]59-captain polkington went in and , sitting down , wrote a hasty note to [Julia]58-julia ; it was to the effect that [he]59-captain polkington had been obliged to go into [town]238-town , but would be back by dark or soon after . It read as quite a casual communication , as if [he]59-captain polkington were in the habit of going into [town]238-town frequently and had much business to transact . [The Captain]172-the captain was rather satisfied with it ; [he]172-the captain felt [he]172-the captain was doing the straightforward thing in telling [Julia]58-julia , [his]172-the captain whole proceedings were open and above board . When [he]59-captain polkington came back [he]59-captain polkington should tell [her]58-julia all about the money , how it had been raised and how spent . [She]58-julia should have had the spending of it [herself]58-julia if only [she]58-julia had gone to [town]238-town when [he]59-captain polkington suggested it ; as it was , [he]59-captain polkington must do it ; it was absurd to wait any longer ; the weather was already cold ; [he]59-captain polkington must go , and bring [her]58-julia some pleasant surprise when [he]59-captain polkington came back . Satisfied with these reflections and feeling already the glow of beneficence , [he]59-captain polkington dressed [himself]59-captain polkington and set out for [Halgrave]47-halgrave . [He]59-captain polkington had to walk to [the village]908-the village and there take [[the carrier]2798-the carrier 's cart which went into [town]238-town]2799-the carrier 's cart which went into town twice a week ; [he]59-captain polkington reflected , while [he]59-captain polkington waited for [the vehicle]2801-the vehicle , how fortunate it was that [Julia]58-julia and [Johnny]57-johnny had chosen to go for the rabbits to - day , one of the days when [the carrier]2798-the carrier went to [town]238-town . There were a good many bundles going by [the cart]2804-the cart , and [two other passengers who were inclined to be too familiar]2805-two other passengers who were inclined to be too familiar until somewhat haughtily shown [their]2805-two other passengers who were inclined to be too familiar proper place . [The Captain]172-the captain was a little annoyed by this ; and annoyed , also , to find that [the carrier]2798-the carrier was not in the habit of starting on the return journey till rather late , later than the note would lead [Julia]58-julia to expect [[her]58-julia father]210-her father . But as [the carrier]2798-the carrier was not one to change [his]2798-the carrier habits for [anybody]2281-anybody , that could not be helped and [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington made the best of it . [Julia]58-julia was not likely to be anxious about [him]59-captain polkington , [he]59-captain polkington was sure ; and since [he]59-captain polkington was going to tell [her]58-julia all about [his]59-captain polkington doings , it might as well be late as early . By this time [he]59-captain polkington had quite got rid of any qualms — if [he]59-captain polkington ever had them — about the method of getting and the intention of spending the note . [He]59-captain polkington had almost forgotten that it had not always been [his]59-captain polkington , and was quite sure that [he]59-captain polkington was doing the right thing — for [others]239-others as well as [himself]59-captain polkington — in the difficult circumstances which seemed to beset [him]59-captain polkington more than the common run of [men]3625-men . Cheered by these thoughts [he]59-captain polkington endured the discomforts of the journey with moderate patience ; [he]59-captain polkington almost felt that [he]59-captain polkington was suffering them in a good cause , for the sake of [Johnny]57-johnny and [Julia]58-julia . [The town]569-the town was large and [the centre of [a large district]2815-a large district , not at all like [the retired gentility of [Marbridge]61-denah]2816-the retired gentility of marbridge]2814-the centre of a large district , not at all like the retired gentility of marbridge , very much bigger and busier . [Captain Polkington]59-captain polkington , who had lived quietly so long , felt rather lost and bewildered at first in [the bustling intricate streets]2817-the bustling intricate streets ; there were [so many people]2818-so many people , especially among [the shops]2819-the shops , [they]2818-so many people were always getting in [his]59-captain polkington way . [He]59-captain polkington only made one purchase before lunch ; [he]59-captain polkington would have plenty of time in the afternoon , [he]59-captain polkington thought , and would be better able to decide what to buy when [he]59-captain polkington had seen things and had a meal . The purchase made before lunch was at [the wine merchants]2820-the wine merchants , it was whisky . [He]59-captain polkington lunched at [the best hotel]2821-the best hotel ; that and the whisky made a rather bigger hole in the five pound note than one would have expected . Still , as [he]59-captain polkington told [himself]59-captain polkington the whisky really was a vital matter with winter coming on , a necessity , not a luxury , for all of [them]2822-them — [Johnny]57-johnny would be better for a little — [he]57-johnny used to like a glass in the old days ; and [Julia]58-julia would certainly be the better for it , working as [she]58-julia did in the cold . It was a medicine for [them]2822-them all , not [himself]59-captain polkington alone . The lunch was the only personal extravagance and really , seeing what [he]59-captain polkington was doing for [the others]312-the others , there was no need for [him]59-captain polkington to grudge that to [himself]59-captain polkington . So [he]59-captain polkington lunched and then the trouble began . [He]59-captain polkington was not clear quite how it happened ; at least , owing to the confusion there always was in [his]59-captain polkington mind between facts as they were , as [he]59-captain polkington wished them to be , and as they appeared in retrospect — [he]59-captain polkington was never able to explain it thoroughly . There were [other men]3724-other men lunching at the same time ; [he]59-captain polkington still had [the Polkington]59-captain polkington faculty for making [friends and ac quaintances]2825-friends and ac quaintances ; [he]59-captain polkington still , too , had the appearance and manner of [a gentleman]3384-a gentleman , if of somewhat reduced circumstances . [He]59-captain polkington apparently made [acquaintances]485-acquaintances ; exactly how many and what sort is not certain , the account was very confused here . There was a whisky and soda in it , two whiskies and sodas , or even three ; a cigar , a game of billiards — perhaps there was more than one game , or some other game besides billiards . At all events there must have been something more , for [the Captain]172-the captain afterwards declared [he]59-captain polkington was ruined in less than an hour , fleeced , cheated of [his]59-captain polkington little all ! It is quite possible that [he]59-captain polkington was [nothing of the kind]2829-nothing of the kind , and that [the acquaintances]2830-the acquaintances were perfectly honest and [honourable men]2831-honourable men . [They]2830-the acquaintances would not know [he]59-captain polkington could not afford to lose , [a true Polkington]2832-a true polkington always set out to hide the reality of [his]59-captain polkington poverty . And [he]59-captain polkington was not likely to win , [he]59-captain polkington seldom did , no matter at what [he]59-captain polkington played or with whom ; [he]59-captain polkington was constitutionally unlucky — or incapable , which is a truer name for the same thing — it had always been so , even as far back as the old times in [India]54-india . That day [he]59-captain polkington lost at something , that at least was clear ; then there was more whisky and soda and more losses , and perhaps more whisky again ; and so on until late in the afternoon , [he]59-captain polkington found [himself]59-captain polkington standing , miserable and bewildered , in [the main street of [the town]569-the town]2833-the main street of the town . [Some one]3318-some one had brought [him]59-captain polkington [there]180-there , [a good - natured young fellow who thought , not that [he]59-captain polkington had spent all [he]59-captain polkington ought]2837-a good - natured young fellow who thought , not that he had spent all he ought , but that [he]59-captain polkington had drunk all [he]59-captain polkington should . " Not used to it , [you]59-captain polkington know , "[2837-a good - natured young fellow who thought , not that he had spent all he ought] [he]2837-a good - natured young fellow who thought , not that he had spent all he ought had said with good - humoured apology ; " been rusticating out of the way so long . Better come out and get a breath of air , it 'll pull [you]59-captain polkington together . "[2837-a good - natured young fellow who thought , not that he had spent all he ought] And [he]2837-a good - natured young fellow who thought , not that he had spent all he ought persuaded [him]59-captain polkington out , walked some way down [the street]366-the street with [him]59-captain polkington and then , seeing that [he]59-captain polkington seemed all right , left [him]59-captain polkington and went to attend to [his]59-captain polkington own business . For a little [the Captain]172-the captain stood where [he]172-the captain was , the depression , begotten of whisky and [his]172-the captain losses , growing upon [him]172-the captain in the old overwhelming way . [No one]181-no one took any notice of [him]172-the captain ; [passers by]2841-passers by jostled against [him]172-the captain , for [the pavement]682-the pavement was rather narrow , but [no one]181-no one paid any attention to [him]172-the captain . The bustle bewildered [his]172-the captain weak head , and the noise and movement of the traffic in [the roadway]2844-the roadway irritated [him]172-the captain unreasonably . [A youth]2845-a youth ran into [him]172-the captain and [he]172-the captain exploded angrily with sudden weak unrestrained fury . Thereat [the boy]930-the boy laughed , and , when [he]930-the boy shouted and stamped [his]930-the boy foot , ran away saying something impudent . [The Captain]172-the captain turned to run after [him]930-the boy shaking [his]172-the captain stick ; but [he]172-the captain was stiff and rheumatic and weak on [his]172-the captain legs , too , just now . It was no use to try and run . Of course it was no use , nothing was any use now , [he]172-the captain was a miserable failure , [he]172-the captain could not even run after [a boy]3999-a boy ; [he]172-the captain must bear [every one]582-every one 's taunts ; [he]172-the captain could almost have wept in self - pity . Then [he]172-the captain became aware that [several passers by]2850-several passers by were looking at [him]172-the captain curiously , arrested by the noise [he]172-the captain had made . Annoyed and ashamed [he]172-the captain turned [his]172-the captain back on [them]2850-several passers by and pretended to be examining the goods in [a shop]2851-a shop window near . It was [a large [draper]2853-draper 's]2852-a large draper 's , rather a cheap one ; [the better shops]2854-the better shops were higher up [the street]366-the street . In this one the things were all priced and labelled plainly ; [the Captain]172-the captain at first did not notice this one way or the other ; [he]172-the captain simply looked in to cover [his]172-the captain confusion . But after a little [he]172-the captain became aware of what [he]172-the captain looked at , and it recalled to [his]172-the captain mind the fact that [he]172-the captain was going to buy something for [Julia]58-julia . [He]172-the captain did not quite know what , [he]172-the captain had had large ideas at one time ; they had had to be diminished once because five pounds will not do as much as twenty ; they had to be diminished again because [he]172-the captain had been fleeced of so much of the five pounds . A wave of anger shook [him]172-the captain as [he]172-the captain thought of that , but [he]172-the captain suppressed it ; [he]172-the captain felt that [he]172-the captain must not give way , so [he]172-the captain looked steadily at the window . There were furs displayed there , muffs and collarettes of skunk and other animals , even the humble rabbit artistically treated to meet the insatiable female appetite for sable at all prices . [The Captain]172-the captain decided on the best collarette displayed and turned towards [the shop]2442-the shop door feeling a little better in the glow of benevolence that returned to [him]172-the captain as [he]172-the captain thought of how much [he]172-the captain was going to spend for [Julia]58-julia . Just as [he]172-the captain was going in [he]172-the captain caught sight of [a girl]201-a girl selling violets in [the street]366-the street . [She]201-a girl was [a good - looking impudent girl]2861-a good - looking impudent girl , and catching [his]172-the captain eye [she]201-a girl pressed [her]201-a girl wares on [him]172-the captain glibly ; [he]172-the captain hesitated , smiled — here was one who treated [him]172-the captain as [a man , who considered it worth while]2862-a man , who considered it worth while . [He]172-the captain looked defiantly at [the passers by]2863-the passers by — [he]172-the captain was [a man]406-a man , not an object for curiosity or kindly contempt . [He]172-the captain returned [the girl]415-the girl 's glance with an ogle and , stepping as jauntily as [he]172-the captain could to the edge of [the pavement]682-the pavement , took a bunch of flowers with some suitable pleasantry . Half - way through [his]172-the captain remark [he]172-the captain stopped dead ; [he]172-the captain had felt in [his]172-the captain pocket for a penny and found nothing . Quickly , feverishly , almost desperately , [he]172-the captain felt in the other pocket ; there were three coins there ; by the size [he]172-the captain could tell that one at least was a penny ; [he]172-the captain took it out and gave it to [the girl]415-the girl ; [he]172-the captain had not the courage to put down the flowers and go without them . Then [he]172-the captain turned away . [A narrow passage]2868-a narrow passage ran down between [the draper]2869-the draper 's and [the next house]2870-the next house ; [fewer people]2871-fewer people went that way and in the window there , common and less expensive goods were displayed . [The Captain]172-the captain went down the foot - way and examined the two remaining coins . They were a shilling and a penny . [People]3334-people passed and repassed along [the main road]2874-the main road ; [carts]2875-carts and [carriages]2876-carriages rumbled over the uneven stones ; [no one]181-no one heeded [the shabby hopeless figure by the side window]2878-the shabby hopeless figure by the side window . [They]2879-they were lighting up in [the draper 's]2880-the draper 's though outside there was still daylight ; the gas jets were considered to make [the place]241-the place look more attractive . They shone warmly on the furs and silk scarves in the front window , making them look rich and luxurious . [Two girls]2882-two girls stopped to look in ; then , [their]2882-two girls means being more suitable to the goods there , [they]2882-two girls came to examine the side window . [They]2882-two girls were [two servants]2883-two servants out for the afternoon ; [they]2882-two girls wore winter coats open over summer dresses and hats that might be called autumnal , seeing that [they]2882-two girls were an ingenious blending of the best that was left from the headgear of both seasons . " [I]338-the other shall get one of them woolly neck things , [I]338-the other shall , "[338-the other] one said ; " they 're quite as nice as fur and not so dear . "[338-the other] [The other]338-the other could not agree . " Do n't care about [them]2882-two girls [myself]2885-i , "[2885-i] [she]2885-i said ; " [I]2885-i must say [I]2885-i like a bit of sable . "[2885-i] " Ca n't get it under two and eleven , "[684-her companion] [[her]2885-i companion]684-her companion rejoined ; " and those things are only a shilling three . Look at that pink one there ; it looks quite as good as feathers any day .
